title: 106_hr263
content: The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes an excise tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payments in factoring transactions, as outlined in Chapter 55 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes a 50 percent tax on acquiring structured settlement payment rights in factoring transactions, with exceptions for court-approved hardships. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" defines a structured settlement as an arrangement for periodic payments of damages or compensation that are excludable from gross income. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" defines structured settlement payment rights as rights to receive payments under a structured settlement, and a structured settlement factoring transaction as a transfer of these payment rights for consideration. A structured settlement factoring transaction involves the transfer of structured settlement payment rights for consideration, with a factoring discount calculated as the difference between the total payments acquired and the amount paid by the acquirer. The relevant court or administrative authority refers to the jurisdiction overseeing the underlying action resolved by the structured settlement. The term 'relevant court or administrative authority' in structured settlement transactions refers to the jurisdiction that had oversight over the underlying action resolved by the structured settlement. This includes the court or administrative authority with jurisdiction over the claim or the residence of the structured settlement recipient. Coordination with other provisions such as sections 72, 130, and 461(h) is required if the structured settlement factoring transaction meets the necessary requirements at the time of entering into the agreement. In structured settlement transactions, coordination with other provisions like sections 72, 130, and 461(h) is necessary if the requirements were met at the time of entering into the agreement. The Secretary is authorized to clarify the treatment of amounts received by the structured settlement recipient in the event of a structured settlement factoring transaction. Information reporting requirements are also amended to include reporting on structured settlement transactions. The reporting requirements for structured settlement factoring transactions are outlined in SEC. 6050T. In structured settlement factoring transactions, the person making the payments must provide a written statement to the acquirer of the payment rights as required by SEC. 6050T. The section outlines the reporting obligations for structured settlement factoring transactions, specifying the coordination with other provisions and defining the term 'acquirer of the structured settlement payment rights'. Additionally, clerical amendments are made to the Code. The amendments in Chapter 55 introduce reporting requirements for structured settlement factoring transactions, with an effective date for transactions occurring after the enactment of the Act.
